chapter.title: Building native binaries

note.para: The Gradle support for building native binaries is currently incubating. Please be aware that the DSL and other configuration may change in later Gradle versions.

chapter.para: The various native binary plugins add support for building native software components from C++, C and Assembler sources. While many excellent build tools exist for this space of software development, Gradle offers developers it's trademark power and flexibility together with the dependency management practices more traditionally found in the JVM development space.

section.title: Tool chain support
section.para: Gradle offers the ability to execute the same build using different tool chains. At present, you control which tool chain will be used to build by changing the operating system PATH to include the desired tool chain compiler. The following tool chains are supported:

tr.td: Windows XP and later, using GCC distributed with Cygwin.
Windows XP and later, Visual C++ 2010 and later.

section.para: Currently, there is no direct support for creating multiple variants of the same binary (e.g. 32 bit vs. 64 bit) and there is no direct support for cross platform source configuration (à la autoconf) at this time. Support for different compiler chains, managing multiple variants and cross platform source configuration will be added over time, making Gradle a fully capable build tool for C++ (and other “native” language) projects.

section.title: Component model
section.para: A native binary project defines a set of and components, each of which Gradle maps to a number of outputs. For each executable or library defined, Gradle adds a with the same name. Each of these functional source sets will contain a language-specific source set for each of the languages supported by the project.
To build either a static or shared native library binary, a component is added to the libraries container. Each library component can produce at least one and at least one .
To build an executable binary, an component is added to the executables container and associated with a set of sources.

section.title: Tasks
section.para: For each that can be produced by a build, a single lifecycle task is constructed that can be used to create that binary, together with a set of sub-tasks that do the actual work of compiling, linking or assembling the binary.

section.title: Working with shared libraries
section.para: For each executable binary produced, the cpp plugin provides an install${binary.name} task, which creates a development install of the executable, along with the shared libraries it requires. This allows you to run the executable without needing to install the shared libraries in their final locations.

section.title: Supported Languages: C, C++ and Assembler
section.para: Presently, Gradle supports building native binaries from any combination of C++, C and Assembler sources. A native binary project will contain one or more named FunctionalSourceSet instances (eg 'main', 'test', etc), each of which can contain LanguageSourceSets containing C++, C or Assembler source files.

section.title: C++ support
section.para: C++ language support is provided by means of the 'cpp' plugin.

C++ sources to be included in a native binary are provided via a , which defines a set of C++ source files and optionally a set of exported header files (for a library). By default, for any named component the contains .cpp source files in src/${name}/cpp, and header files in src/${name}/headers.
While the cpp plugin defines these default locations for each , it is possible to extend or override these defaults to allow for a different project layout.

For a library named 'main', files in src/main/headers are considered the “public” or “exported” headers. Header files that should not be exported (but are used internally) should be placed inside the src/main/cpp directory (though be aware that such header files should always be referenced in a manner relative to the file including them).

section.title: C support
section.para: C language support is provided by means of the 'c' plugin.

C sources to be included in a native binary are provided via a , which defines a set of C source files and optionally a set of exported header files (for a library). By default, for any named component the contains .c source files in src/${name}/c, and header files in src/${name}/headers.
While the c plugin defines these default locations for each , it is possible to extend or override these defaults to allow for a different project layout.

For a library named 'main', files in src/main/headers are considered the “public” or “exported” headers. Header files that should not be exported (but are used internally) should be placed inside the src/main/c directory (though be aware that such header files should always be referenced in a manner relative to the file including them).

section.title: Assembler support
section.para: Assembly language support is provided by means of the 'assembler' plugin.

Assembler sources to be included in a native binary are provided via a , which defines a set of Assembler source files. By default, for any named component the contains .s source files under src/${name}/asm.

section.title: Library Dependencies
section.para: Dependencies for C++ projects are binary libraries that export header files. The header files are used during compilation, with the compiled binary dependency being used during the linking.

section.title: Publishing
section.para: The cpp-exe and cpp-lib plugins configure their respective output binaries to be publishable as part of the archives configuration. To publish, simply configure the uploadArchives task as per usual.

The cpp-exe plugin publishes a single artifact with extension “exe”. The cpp-lib plugin publishes two artifacts; one with classifier “headers” and extension “zip”, and one with classifier “so” and extension “so” (which is the format used when consuming dependencies).

note.para: Currently, there is no support for publishing the dependencies of artifacts in POM or Ivy files. Future versions will support this.
